title: Before 1 July 2018, will the Council of the European Union adopt a directive on taxation of digital business activities?
preds:
Joint Industry statement ahead of the 28-29 June European Council 
https://www.itic.org/news-events/news-releases/business-and-tech-groups-raise-concerns-about-eu-digital-taxation-proposal Not enough time for this to happen even though it will before the end of this year.
I had no idea so I went off consensus of other forecasters.
Affirming. Germany's finance minister "torpedoed the idea" according to https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/german-politics-risks-affecting-the-eurozone-reform/

“Radikale Steuerreform: Merkel Will Daten Besteuern,” May 29, 2018. http://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/unternehmen/radikale-steuerreform-merkel-will-daten-besteuern-15612688.html.
“Steuerreform: Angela Merkel Fordert Besteuerung von Daten | ZEIT ONLINE,” Mai 2018. https://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2018-05/steuerreform-angela-merkel-daten-eu.
----------- Germany and France expect large windfall income from taxation. That's like going to the tailor and a government agent wants the tailor and client to pay for merely taking measures; and churches need to pay, too, because the community posts on the bulletin board.
The timescale is too short and at least four EU members would be inclined to veto.
Given the time frame and the speed of EU bodies, I'm going with no.
More countries turning against the proposal: https://www.law360.com/tax-authority/articles/1044619/germany-netherlands-turning-against-eu-digital-tax
following @emil adding taxed implies domestic application (not a tariff)
intent is there, timeline too soon

There is only one Council meeting within this short time frame which is at the end of June [1]. A passage in June would be exceptionally quick given that the Commission's proposal came out as recently as March 21.  The unanimity requirement on fiscal matters (which includes the UK's vote) is a major hurdle. Ireland, Luxembourg, and Malta are likely to object. And the list of dissenters could be bigger. Scandinavian countries have voiced concerns as well [2]. Some countries will be worried about aggravating trade relations with the U.S. It is no coincidence that the proposal is informally referred to as the GAFA tax. On top of it all the EC's proposal is not the solution most countries are looking for but presented by the EC as a temporary fix in the interim. The EC wants urgent action but that is not necessarily the case with member states. [1]http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/calendar/?filters=2031
[2] https://www.politico.eu/article/bruno-le-maire-digital-tax-france-left-isolated-in-fight-as-uk-backs-away/
